paragraphs.text: From Ferguson to immigration: Obama's divide and conquer political strategy has failed our nation.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: A recent Quinnipiac poll shows support for illegal immigrants at 48 percent, a historic low
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: This is what the president's cynical manipulation of the Hispanic community has delivered: a hardening of American attitudes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The same distancing will likely occur between blacks and whites as the demonstrations over the grand jury decisions in Ferguson and Staten Island roll on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Whereas
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: only recently a sizable majority of blacks and whites declared themselves comfortable with the state of race relations in the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: pictures of looting and the inflammatory rhetoric of self-interested activists like Al Sharpton will inevitably sharpen racial divides
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The insistent proclamations from Attorney General Eric Holder that our justice system is biased, and the president's agreement that the law "feels like it's being applied in a discriminatory fashion," do not help
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Today, Obama's well-honed political tactics of dividing and conquering-- so essential to electing a virtual nobody to the Oval Office-- have come asunder
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The interest groups wooed by the president have begun to turn against him
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some feel betrayed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: others understand that their demands have isolated them from their fellow countrymen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The only group still giving the president more than a 50 percent approval rating is voters under 3
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: For the rest of the poor boobs not caught up in the Obama splinter sweep-- they are eager to elect a successor who might look out for them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Turns out, those forgotten folks are actually in the majority, and just voted in a Republican Senate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to the Quinnipiac poll, 48 percent of voters think immigrants living in the U.S  illegally should be allowed to stay
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: That's down from 57 percent last year, and lower than ever
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Moreover
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some 35 percent of the voting public thinks undocumented aliens should be deported -- a record high, and up from 26 percent last year
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: That's in spite of insistent hectoring from the White House about the moral imperative of providing a legal path for those who are here illegally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Congratulations, Mr  Obama, for ramping up opposition to immigration reform
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: How to deal with illegal immigrants is not the only issue on which the nation's attitudes are hardening
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last August, after the shooting of Michael Brown (but before the grand jury decision in the case), a New York Times/CBS poll surveyed voters on their attitudes about race
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Asked whether race relations had improved or soured during President Obama's time in office, 35 percent of respondents said they had gotten worse
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: 52 percent said they had stayed the same
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Only 10 percent thought the president had had a positive impact on relations - 8 percent of whites and 17 percent of blacks
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: That is an impressive underachievement from our first African-American president
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Overall
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: 78 percent of respondents, when asked about "race relations in your community," said they were "generally good."
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: That included 82 percent of whites and 73 percent of blacks -- a strong vote of confidence, especially from a group that was much less positive about the country as a whole, with only 47 percent saying U.S  race relations were "generally good."
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: This split suggests that people have absorbed the narrative that our country has a race problem not from their personal experience in their own communities, but from the media or our political leaders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The most compelling aspect of that story line entails racial bias in law enforcement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many initiatives, from decriminalizing marijuana possession to de-emphasizing tactics like "stop and frisk," have been promulgated based on the fact that more blacks than whites end up on the wrong side of the law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Holder has even dumbed down school discipline measures, arguing they constitute an example of racial bias
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Manhattan Institute's Steve Malanga sheds some welcome light on this issue
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to surveys conducted by the federal Bureau of Justice Statistics over the past 20 years, the number of confrontations between Americans and the police has declined, as has the use of force by law enforcement officials
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Most important, perhaps, is that the declines were recorded not just for whites, but for all races
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: In 2002, 173,000 African-Americans reported a "use of force"; in 2011, that was down to 130,000
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Nearly 83 percent of blacks who were involved in traffic stops(the most numerous encounters) agreed with the statement,"When I was stopped by the police, the officers acted properly."
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: That figure was up from 78 percent in 2002
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: As for so-called "street stops," the Bureau reports,"In 2011, less than 1% of the 241.4 million U.S  residents age 16 or older were involved in a street stop"
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: further
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: "no differences were observed in the percentage of non-Hispanic white, non-Hispanic black, and Hispanic populations age 16 or older involved in a street stop."
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: So much for unfair profiling
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Under 3 percent of police encounters involve "street stops" of an involuntary nature
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: of those stopped (likely not a happy crew), two-thirds said the cops behaved "properly and respectfully."
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: This review does not suggest a law enforcement community reviled by the African-American community, or the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: President Obama has tried to curry favor with blacks, Hispanics, women, the young and the poor by convincing them that they suffer from injustices, that they are victimized by the one percent, by law enforcement, by corporations or insurers -- or by Republicans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Americans aren't buying it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Increasingly, they see a country victimized by an incompetent president
paragraphs.label: assumption
